review There is a fine line between good Christmas-cheesy and bad Christmas-cheesy. This is the story of Noelle and Gabriel (let the cheese commence). Noelle There is a fine line between good Christmas-cheesy and bad Christmas-cheesy. This is the story of Noelle and Gabriel (let the cheese commence). Noelle runs a Christmas store (of course) which she opened in the town of Fool's Gold (really?) after a bout of Leukemia chased off her fiance and her employer. Gabriel is a trauma doctor for the US Army serving on life flights out of war zones with "break" rotations in Germany. He is understandably scarred and has an extreme commitment phobia. I don't know if it's because the book was a contemporary romance instead of a historical or just that their personal hills were very high and hard to climb or maybe I've just over-indulged in the genre during the last two weeks, but I rolled my eyes at the idea of these two people overcoming their extreme emotional baggage in 6 weeks to end up together in a Christmas package tied up with a nice neat little bow. My eyes hurt from the rolling and I had the urge a couple of times to throw the book across the wall in frustration from the cheesiness. ...more

review Dr. Fraser is the man who hears Mr. Bingham's deathbed confession that Mary Surratt divulged a truth during the Lincoln assassination trial that would Dr. Fraser is the man who hears Mr. Bingham's deathbed confession that Mary Surratt divulged a truth during the Lincoln assassination trial that would rock the foundation of the nation. So he partners with a colored newspaper man and sets out to find out who was really the person pulling the strings for the assassination. It sounds to me as though David Stewart found an interesting nugget during his research, but not enough to substantiate it for there to be a non-fiction book. To explore his option, it had to be a fictionalized account. I think in the hands of a fiction writer, this could have been a page turner. Instead it was rather flat and I found myself reading chunks more through force of will than because I had to know what happens next. All-in-all a bit disappointing. ...more

review I have a love/hate relationship with books published by Christian labels. Either it just means there's no swearing or bedroom scenes or it means the c I have a love/hate relationship with books published by Christian labels. Either it just means there's no swearing or bedroom scenes or it means the characters have to overtly profess their faith on a regular basis. I have no problem with the former, but my personal faith is a quiet one and so ubiquitous professions of faith grates on me or feel forced. Unfortunately, I thought this book fell into the latter generalization, which colored my enjoyment of it. Adele is a Christian. She lives in Austria and plays violin with the Vienna Philharmonic during WWII. She is in love with Vladimir and is caught by the SS while trying sneak a Jewish family out of Austria. There is an extant painting of her as an Auschwitz prisoner which has haunted art historian Sera since she was 8 years old. William learns that the painting is key to the stipulations laid out in his grandfather's will and teams up with Sera to research the painting's provenance. As William and Sera trace the painting, they try to overcome their hesitations over the budding romance between them. The descriptions of Adele's life in Auschwitz were haunting. I did a little more research into the Auschwitz women's orchestra and was impressed that the author wove in actual members to her fictional account. I never felt like Sera or William learned any of Adele's story until the end of the book. There was something about her story's ending that didn't sit well with me, but I can't put my finger on why exactly it bothered me. I thought the contemporary storyline was trite. William and Sera had a "whirlwind romance" with a complete lack of passion (and I don't mean to imply that there needed to be physical passion). William's hesitation was never fully explained and their storyline was wrapped up abruptly. ...more

review I wanted more from this book. I wanted there to be more Kenya, more history and more resolution with Bea. The backdrop was superfluous to the story an I wanted more from this book. I wanted there to be more Kenya, more history and more resolution with Bea. The backdrop was superfluous to the story and I wish it had more bearing as it was a fascinating period of history. I wish this had been written as a generational saga with a linear timeline instead of the back and forth between modern and historical stories. This method of story-telling robbed the narrative of some of the suspense and history. Certain events HAD to happen because otherwise Clemmie's story wouldn't have happened, and these were unveiled in Chapter One. That being said, the characters were, as always, well written and fleshed out. I read large chunks of the book at a time because Lauren Willig is an impressive storyteller and I found myself having a hard time putting the book down. ...more

review Carrie is a society-page writer for a major newspaper in Chicago, but wants her career to be more. Finn is a loner who managed to write a best-selling Carrie is a society-page writer for a major newspaper in Chicago, but wants her career to be more. Finn is a loner who managed to write a best-selling novel and has been trying to hide from his fame ever since. Carrie's editor tells her that if she lands an interview with the illusive Finn she can have any assignment she chooses. Which is how she winds up in the Alaskan tundra... Debbie Macomber weaves a charming Christmas romance, a genre at which she excels. My enjoyment of this one was a bit marred by having lived in Alaska. Some of her details rang true, some did not (Finn lives "outside of Fairbanks near the arctic circle." I've made that drive. It took several hours. I don't consider it outside of Fairbanks). However I liked Carrie and Finn and the way that their love coaxes Finn out of his shell. It was a nice heart-warming tale for the holidays. ...more

review Alice's father has a mysterious conversation with a fairy which prompts him to take a trip. He dies when his boat sinks on the ocean, leaving Alice in Alice's father has a mysterious conversation with a fairy which prompts him to take a trip. He dies when his boat sinks on the ocean, leaving Alice in the care of "Uncle" Geryon. When Alice arrives, she finds that Geryon has a library full of magic books. Alice is a Reader who can read her way into books. This sends Alice on a journey full of intrigue and scheming while she finds out who she can and cannot trust and also about her new found abilities. I liked this book very much. It was interesting how the Readers can pull book elements into real life. I found the beginning and the ending to be page turners, but there was a bit in the middle which became rather slow. I look forward to the next installment. ...more

review Frank Blackthorne is a thief, except his most recent heist goes somewhat awry when the Temple of Natlac is not as empty as he was told... After rescui Frank Blackthorne is a thief, except his most recent heist goes somewhat awry when the Temple of Natlac is not as empty as he was told... After rescuing the then-virgin, Frank takes a job to rescue a Princess from a dragon so that perhaps he can turn his luck around. But that doesn't go so well either after a spell has some unintended consequences of putting Frank's soul into the princess' body. Hijinks ensue as the thief-turned-princess and princess-turned-dragon search for the Evil Wizard so their souls can be returned to the correct bodies. The book was as humorous as the cover said it was going to be. I loved the interactions between Frank and Lucille as well as Frank's problems finding himself in the body of a nubile princess. The "bad guys" were delightfully twisted and caused no end of issues for poor Frank. I look forward to a second book. ...more

review I wanted to not just like this book, I wanted to love it. Who wouldn't the story of the indomitable Mammy? I wanted to like it so much that I did mana I wanted to not just like this book, I wanted to love it. Who wouldn't the story of the indomitable Mammy? I wanted to like it so much that I did manage to finish reading it. But it was dull as dishwater. At times the sentence structure was too confusing to follow and I found myself reading the same passage several times. ...more

review Spencer's mom believes in service to the community and when he starts 6th grade begins dropping him off at a senior citizen's home so he can give back Spencer's mom believes in service to the community and when he starts 6th grade begins dropping him off at a senior citizen's home so he can give back as well. Spencer befriends Ed and one day Ed shows him Pandora's Book. By following a particular pattern, people can leap off the page and come to life. He entrusts the book's care the Spencer, but ran out of time to teach him how to use it. Gregor, Spencer's autistic friend, accidentally brings Socrates to life. When he tries calling Ed to find out how to put Socrates back in the book, Spencer finds out that Ed has disappeared. So Gregor and Spencer are found by Frank diCarlo (who has Pandora's Other Book) and Ed's granddaughter, Mel. Together, the group seek out the Bad Guy to save Ed and keep the world safe. The premise of this book was interesting. I liked the addition of Gregor's autism, it added another level of strength to the characters, both his and Spencer's. It was very much a story of friendship in how protective Spencer is of Gregor and how brave Gregor is in battling his autistic tendencies to help Spencer. It's always fun to see how an author integrates historical figures into a fictional account. ...more

review Clementine is a 44-year-old woman who lives with her crotchety drunk of a father who is a vigneron in Champagne, France. When Olivier dies, she is the Clementine is a 44-year-old woman who lives with her crotchety drunk of a father who is a vigneron in Champagne, France. When Olivier dies, she is the heir apparent to the winery. The family lawyer bursts her bubble by informing her that she must share the estate with not only the half-sister who she perceives as ruining her life some 20 years before, but a third sister who the other two were unaware of and any children the three may have. Mathilde arrives to escape her life and Sophie arrives to find hers. This was not as charming as The Wedding Bees: A Novel of Honey, Love, and Manners. I was a little disappointed that Ms. Lynch needed a fairy godmother-esque character to move the story along as the characters were excellent. I loved that the story was a bonding of sisters without needing a disease or unfaithful spouse to cause them to come together. I did find the last scene a little strange as well. I think I would have skipped the last 2 pages, although perhaps with a little more of the champagne described so eloquently in the book it wouldn't have bothered me as much ;) ...more

review The Pursuit of Lucy Banning was a pleasant diversion over the weekend. Lucy is a likeable character at a time where the role of women is drastically c The Pursuit of Lucy Banning was a pleasant diversion over the weekend. Lucy is a likeable character at a time where the role of women is drastically changing. She belongs to the upper echelon of Chicago society, but wants a college degree and falls in love with a working class architect from dubious background. I was a little disappointed that the "backdrop of the Columbian Exposition" promised by the back of the book resulted in little more than several meetings Lucy was required to attend as well as a couple of events glossed over by saying there were speeches and more speeches. I expected more historical content. So if you are looking for a book which has story set against the rich background of the World's Fair... you would be wise to look elsewhere. My biggest issue with the book is that after breaking their engagement, Lucy's fiance becomes a stalker, a storyline which is rather disturbing at times. Despite this, everything wraps up in a nice, beautiful bow by the end of the book. I wish Ms. Newport had chosen to focus more on Lucy's relationship with Will and her pursuit of "un-womanly" interests than continue to string along Daniel. ...more

review This book was a pleasant diversion. It was the From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler meets The Snow Queen. After their mother dies, Oph This book was a pleasant diversion. It was the From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler meets The Snow Queen. After their mother dies, Ophelia and her sister, Alice, follow their father on his assignment to a museum. He is a sword expert and he is assisting in putting together an exhibit of amazing swords which is to open the same night the Wintertide clock chimes. While exploring the museum, Ophelia discovers the Marvelous Boy who has been locked away for 300 years. He enlists Ophelia's help in setting him free and finding the One Other who is the only person who can defeat the Snow Queen. It wasn't a particularly gripping story or as enchanting as others I've read, but I enjoyed watching Ophelia learn and grow as she follows the boy's tale and instructions. The ending was quite satisfying. ...more

review Sookie is the only daughter of Lenore Simmons (aka Winged Victory). She handles Lenore's life as Lenore is getting old and is insisting that she will Sookie is the only daughter of Lenore Simmons (aka Winged Victory). She handles Lenore's life as Lenore is getting old and is insisting that she will not move into an Assisted Living home. One day, life changes when Sookie receives a registered letter from Texas. The resulting narrative follows Sookie as she comes to grips with the surprising news as well as the lives of 4 sisters who ran the All-Girl Filling Station and served as WASPs in WWII. I cannot say enough about this book. It was full of the unique Southern women that Ms. Flagg is known for and Sookie's family and friends provided many laughs. I also loved her foray into the lives of the Polish women from Wisconsin. Fritzi and her sisters were delightful. The historical information about the WASPs was fascinating. I enjoyed hearing about these women's lives. The book was finished off beautifully and I closed the back cover after having shed a few tears. (Although Lenore is a force of nature... even in death!) ...more

review This genre is built upon storylines where the main characters do something generally stupid. This book had main characters who were exceedingly stupid This genre is built upon storylines where the main characters do something generally stupid. This book had main characters who were exceedingly stupid on multiple levels. Julian Swift returns from war. He is determined to break off his understanding with Penelope and marry Cassandra, who wrote him faithfully for 7 years. He enters a room with Lucy and Cassandra, but does not recognize the stunning beauty as the current incarnation of the gawky 16-year-old he left behind. So Lucy decides to pretend that Cassandra is Patience Bunbury and herself Lady Worthing so that Cass can have time with Julian before he meets Penelope to (supposedly) marry her. Titled London society is just not that large for two women who are at the center of a social circle to pass themselves off as fictional people. Particularly when one is a Duchess with two different colored eyes and the other still has family in the area. I spent much of this book wanting to toss it against the wall, which is a shame because I remember enjoying The Unexpected Duchess. The last book in the series is about Jane and Garrett. They are my favorite characters and I hope that their story lives up to my expectations... and that Lucy appears in thimble-full quantities. ...more

review I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Caroline and Michael were caught together on a balcony 11 years previously. Michael fled the scene and has been forced I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Caroline and Michael were caught together on a balcony 11 years previously. Michael fled the scene and has been forced to return 11-years later to find an heiress to marry so he can save his dukedom. Caroline is a wealthy widow who has become a social darling and promises to help Michael overcome his social anxiety and find a wife. She hopes this will cure her of her youthful infatuation forever. Michael just can't figure out what Caro wants. I liked that Ms. Romain flipped the gender-role table in this book. The hero of the book is the ingenue (for lack of a better term) while the heroine has more worldly experience. Caroline was not willing to compromise on what she wants from life to help Michael out of his predicament and Michael was realistic in his befuddlement of why Caroline would not respond to his logical assessment of situations. All in all it was quite a diverting read. I didn't want to put it down! ...more

review As a boy, William Bellman kills a rook with his catapult. He pushes it to the back of his brain never to be thought of again. But the rooks remember. A As a boy, William Bellman kills a rook with his catapult. He pushes it to the back of his brain never to be thought of again. But the rooks remember. As Bellman grows, he is shadowed by this one event. He is a successful businessman who runs a mill (we learn in excruciating detail) and one by one, his loved ones die, culminating in an epidemic which takes his wife and 3 of 4 children. As his favorite daughter lay dying, he makes a deal with Black. I continued with the book up until this point because I wanted to know where it was going. It was going to the construction and running of Bellman & Black, a department store for the mourning. Which we also learn about in excruciating detail. By this point the book slowed to a crawl, but being only 100 pages from the end I soldiered on to the not-so-satisfying resolution. I don't know what I wanted. I guess if his daughter was important enough to give up his soul for, I think he should have had some kind of relationship with her and she was an afterthought through the second half of the book. What a disappointment since I enjoyed the Thirteenth Tale so much. ...more

review **spoiler alert** Arrr.... I think Ms. Katsu must have run out of ideas before she wrote this book. Lanore finds herself alone after Luke's death and d **spoiler alert** Arrr.... I think Ms. Katsu must have run out of ideas before she wrote this book. Lanore finds herself alone after Luke's death and decides that Adair is her One True Love. But she is plagued by dreams of Jonathan, who is being held hostage and tortured by the queen of the underworld. She seeks out Adair to request that he help her rescue Jonathan. So she travels to the underworld and we are treated to a Ghost of Christmas Past trek through her life and damage she left in her path. In the meantime Adair, is held in thrall by two witch sisters who... well... they don't really seem to do much of anything. But then, we wind up with the most fantastic literary device ever employed: The deus ex machina ending. But we couldn't stop there... the main character wound up being a deus. Literally. He was the King of the Underworld, but left to escape his shrew of a wife who was also his sister. But then dad (Capital-G God) shows up and turns him mortal again so he can live a normal life with his one true love. Except the problem is that I never really understood Lanore and Adair's Grand Love Affair. How can two extremely self-centered people have a Grand Love Affair? I never really bought it and the plot of this book was just tiresome. Ugh. ...more

review This book was amazingly written. Caroline is a city-girl who is at crossroads in her life. To complicate matters, her mother has dementia and is rapid This book was amazingly written. Caroline is a city-girl who is at crossroads in her life. To complicate matters, her mother has dementia and is rapidly progressing to a point where she cannot live alone. While readying her mother's cottage for some repair, she discovers and old quilt which belonged to her grandmother. It was not made by her grandmother, but by a woman who her grandmother met during a short stint at an asylum. Caroline sets out to research the quilt's provenance and stumbles upon Maria's story. Maria was a seamstress at Kensington palace during WWI where she catches the eye of the crown prince. Unfortunately, her life at the palace takes a less than idyllic turn and the quilt becomes Maria's outlet. The uncovering of Maria's secret was fascinating and I liked the character of Caroline. She was believable, as were her struggles. I wish I had another 25-50 pages to bring her current journey to another crossroads, however the book was truly about Maria. Maria's story was definitely plausible and I felt awful about the way she was treated. Definitely want to pick up The Last Telegram. ...more

review This was a delightful book. Emily is invited by her cousin to help search out the lost treasure of Queen Isabelle in the Chateau de Chinon. When Henry This was a delightful book. Emily is invited by her cousin to help search out the lost treasure of Queen Isabelle in the Chateau de Chinon. When Henry does not arrive at the train station to meet her, she assumes he's become distracted, which is not at all out of character. In the meantime, she decides to enjoy her holiday and spends it with the motley crew who are also at the hotel. While there she learns of a second Isabelle who also left a treasure in Chinon during WWII. The story picks up pace when Emily determines that something has happened to Henry and she confesses to Paul. They work together to find out where Henry is. This book was not an action book. It was very much a book that worked because the characters were charming and realistic. I liked watching how Emily's relationships between her and Paul, Simon and Neal grew. I liked the comic relief of Thierry and Garland. My only complaint is that I would have liked the thread of the mystery to be woven into the book earlier as the resolution was a bit rushed in the last 75 pages or so of the book. ...more

review I think I would have enjoyed this book more had I read it while on vacation. It needed to be a book read without much concentration because then flaws I think I would have enjoyed this book more had I read it while on vacation. It needed to be a book read without much concentration because then flaws would become more apparent and frustrating. Ellen is a real estate lawyer in NYC. With her (literal) dying breath, Ellen's grandmother tells of a letter that she wants delivered to Chet in Beacon, ME. So off Ellen goes, letter in tow, leaving her fiance with political aspirations behind in New York. The book follows the typical plot line of girl is fish out of water. Girl meets boy who is very different from what she expects of life. Girl decides to... well. You can guess the rest ;) Everything was very compressed. There was no soul searching about what she wants out of life before the big climatic event. I don't know that I would count out reading a second book by this author, but I wish I had been dumping my brain on a beach while reading this one instead of during an average work week. ...more

review Apparently I have a thing about WWII planes crashing in the great white north. Last year I read about the Grumman Duck in Greenland, this year I follo Apparently I have a thing about WWII planes crashing in the great white north. Last year I read about the Grumman Duck in Greenland, this year I followed the story of Leon Crane who crashed in the interior of Alaska. Crane's bomber was out for a routine run to test out the feathering on the propellers when an engine stalled out and the plane crashed. Crane and one other crewmen were able to jump out of the plane, but only Crane survived. He did so by walking out of the forest to safety. It took 81 days in the Alaskan winter for him to do so. Good fortune smiled on him in that he found a cabin with a cache of supplies which allowed him to recover from the crash's aftermath and regain the feeling in his hands as well as upgrade his winter gear. The story itself is relatively simple. It's not as fleshed out as it could have been, not by fault of the author, but because Crane appears to have suffered from survivor's guilt and wouldn't talk much about his ordeal. My only other complaint about the book is that Mr. Murphy found interesting tidbits that were tangentially related to the main story and stuck them into the narrative, disrupting the flow of the book. I would have preferred these as foot/end notes or in an appendix of some kind. An interesting read, made more interesting having lived in Fairbanks for 3 years so I understood the dangers of the weather and the rough geography of the area. ...more

review Sabina Carpenter has been hired to keep an eye on a young debutante who her parents suspect is carrying on a dalliance with an unsuitable young man. W Sabina Carpenter has been hired to keep an eye on a young debutante who her parents suspect is carrying on a dalliance with an unsuitable young man. While at a party, the girl appears to commit suicide and Sabina must work on clearing her name and restoring her reputation. Meanwhile, John Quincannon is attempting to find burglars who robbed Wells, Fargo so he can collect a $3000 reward. Towards the end, the two detectives find that their cases intersect. Unfortunately, that does not mean that they work together. I think the book is at its best when Sabina and John are in the same room, but that only happens for 20 pages or so. I'm guessing due to how the authors are writing the novel. Because they are never together, their dynamic is never quite fleshed out. I may be done with this series. It's lacking a sparkle that other books have and there's too many books I want to read and not enough free time during the day. ...more

review Mickey Rawlings is accused of shooting the head of the IWW union in self-defense, although he knows he didn't do it. The police consider it a shut cas Mickey Rawlings is accused of shooting the head of the IWW union in self-defense, although he knows he didn't do it. The police consider it a shut case and unless Mickey can find definitive proof that someone else was involved, he won't be able to clear his name. Mickey winds up as a pawn in the battle between the baseball owners and players during the fledgling labor movement. This one was not my favorite, although it may be colored by my recent reading of The Daring Ladies of Lowell, which also covered the same subject matter. Like Mickey Rawlings himself, I have a hard time getting behind unionized baseball players when the working conditions for children were terrible. There was almost a little too much going on between the labor movement, suffrage movement and the Detroit auto-factories that no subject was scratched very deeply. However, as always, the baseball details are wonderful and Mickey is a truly delightful protagonist. ...more

review This book started out slowly, but I was quite happy with it by the end. Prue is fired from the traveling variety show on the voyage from America to Eur This book started out slowly, but I was quite happy with it by the end. Prue is fired from the traveling variety show on the voyage from America to Europe. Ophelia quits her job in solidarity and to keep an eye on Prue. She finds employment for them both as servants with a newly married couple on the way to see their castle in Germany. Once there, a cottage is discovered which is supposedly Snow White's. Shortly thereafter, the owner of the castle is murdered with a poisoned apple. From here, a tangled web is woven as groups of characters seek to discover the true identity of the murderer and where Snow White is buried, if she is indeed real. I don't believe anyone in this book is who they say they are. The beauty of it is that you really aren't sure who is who until the very end. Ms. Chance does an impeccable job of gathering all the threads and pulling them together into a plausible ending. I look forward to the next one. ...more

review This book follows an 11-year-old girl on her trip from Quincy, IL to Golden, CO as her father seeks out a better life for her family. When she leaves This book follows an 11-year-old girl on her trip from Quincy, IL to Golden, CO as her father seeks out a better life for her family. When she leaves Quincy, her grandmother presents her with the pieces for a doll-sized Log Cabin quilt. Emmy does not enjoy quilting, but on her journey she learns that quilts bind the women of a community together, be it a town or a wagon train. The author was a bit heavy handed with some of her plot elements. The quilting conversations seemed a bit forced. I also wasn't keen on how the author presented the role of women in pioneer times as being subservient to the husband nor the abusive relationship in the wagon train. It seemed as though the author tried to dumb-down the concepts because the book is written for children, but I think they could have been handled with more finesse. ...more

review While full of sparkling dialogue as always, I found this book to be more lackluster than the rest of the series. Jenny and Elijah spend much of their While full of sparkling dialogue as always, I found this book to be more lackluster than the rest of the series. Jenny and Elijah spend much of their time not finding ways to compromise even though their romantic road block is fairly easy to compromise with. Jenny is an artist at a time when women's art is under-appreciated. Elijah is commissioned to paint a portrait of two of her many nephews. The attraction is, of course, immediate. Jenny insists that Elijah cannot coexist in her dreamland where she is able to study art seriously. Love is blind I guess? Elijah clearly is able to accept Jenny the artist as evidenced by his acceptance of her opinion and his offer to have him assist in his portrait painting sessions. Still, for a Christmas romance, you can't expect much more than what this offers! ...more

review Charlotte has lived in the country for most of her teenage years. Her father died in an accident and the entailed estate was left to a distant cousin. Charlotte has lived in the country for most of her teenage years. Her father died in an accident and the entailed estate was left to a distant cousin. Unbeknownst to her, she was betrothed at birth to a duke who is descended from the illegitimate son of a king. She finds this out in the middle of the night. This book was tiresome. Charlotte was written to act more like a 15-year old, but was actually 18 (probably so as not to offend modern sensibilities). Her innocence was a bit too childish for an Earl's daughter, even one who grew up in the country. The "misunderstandings" between Charlotte and March were annoying and there was not enough friction between the characters to make it interesting read. I couldn't bring myself to abandon the first two books of 2014, which is probably why I didn't give up on it. ...more

review It seems to me that the world around 1800 was ready for a change and it truly didn't matter who was on the throne. Combine some long-rooted animosity It seems to me that the world around 1800 was ready for a change and it truly didn't matter who was on the throne. Combine some long-rooted animosity against Austria and a weak monarch and you have a recipe for revolution. It occurs to me that Marie Antoinette really suffered from a lack of a decent PR department! The book was very interesting, I like the view that Marie Antoinette was not the heinous person history alludes that she was. I had no idea about her frustrations about not being a mother at an early age. The pacing was a bit uneven, at times I felt as though the plot was plodding and other times moved at a brisk clip. I imagine part of the problem is that this book is a bridge between the introduction and the final ending which we all know occurs and I found myself biding my time until the revolution begins. Looking forward to The Last October Sky. ...more

review Jules's father was murdered when she and her half-sister were young. Since then, her sister has become a troubled youth to the point where a judge ord Jules's father was murdered when she and her half-sister were young. Since then, her sister has become a troubled youth to the point where a judge orders her to a private rehabilitation academy so she can avoid juvie. However, something is rotten at the academy. Jules gets herself hired as a teacher so she can uncover what is wrong at the school and spring her sister. And so begins 400 pages of convenient events and shallow characters. There's much navel gazing and wondering the same thing over and over and over. The secondary characters were not fleshed out hardly at all and became integral to the end of the book. All in all, it was a frustrating read because it could have been so much better with a little more work and 100 fewer pages. My 7-year old son picked it out for me, which is the primary reason for it being read to completion. ...more

review Once upon a time, it was discovered that Neil Armstrong was not the first man on the moon... This book received some mediocre reviews. It won't receive Once upon a time, it was discovered that Neil Armstrong was not the first man on the moon... This book received some mediocre reviews. It won't receive one from me. I was completely hooked. I HAD to know what they found on the moon and why it could possibly have been that controversial that it needed to be kept quiet. I liked the way the narrative switched between three points of view. It kept the story clicking along and was a smart way to slowly unfold all of the details surrounding the secret moon missions. I wonder if there was a particular author in charge of each point of view... and if not, how they worked the collaboration. I am a McDevitt fan, but I do not believe I have read anything by Resnick. That situation will need to change soon! ...more
